awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Neurodevelopment of Value-Based Learning and Decision-Making
awd_abstract_narration:
Learning to make choices that bring about good outcomes and avoid bad ones is a lifelong challenge. Such learning is particularly consequential during adolescence, when increased exploration and autonomy confer many opportunities to make new choices. Poor decision-making represents one of the greatest perils of adolescence, with mortality rates doubling during this developmental stage, in large part due to risky or impulsive actions. However, the neural and cognitive mechanisms underpinning this developmental period of increased risky decision-making are not well understood. The overarching goal of this proposal is to characterize how the dynamic developmental trajectory of brain circuitry involved in learning through positive and negative experience shapes real-world choices. Drawing upon behavioral, computational, and neuroimaging approaches, this work will examine how neurocognitive changes in value-based learning may give rise to a window of increased risky and impulsive decision-making during adolescence. A refined understanding of the mechanisms underlying developmental changes in real-world decision-making has broad relevance across a number of societal domains including public policy, adolescent health, and juvenile justice.

This proposal will test whether risky and impulsive choice may stem in part from developmental changes in two specific aspects of how individuals learn from experience: (i) the relative weighting individuals place upon positive versus negative outcomes of past actions and (ii) the degree to which individuals form and recruit mental models of the potential future consequences of their actions. A developmental sample of participants, spanning late childhood to young adulthood, will complete sequential decision-making tasks in which they make a series of choices that can yield good or bad outcomes. By applying computational reinforcement-learning models to participants' choices in these tasks, we can precisely quantify developmental changes in these component processes of learning. Functional magnetic resonance imaging (fMRI) will be used to characterize corresponding developmental changes in the brain circuitry engaged during learning. We will assess whether these neurocognitive changes in learning are predictive of participants' reports of their real-world risky and impulsive behavior, and whether they have distinct explanatory power from that of behavioral economic tasks that are commonly used to index risky and impulsive choice tendencies, but do not involve learning. A longitudinal follow-up session will enable assessment of the covariance between changes in learning and real-world risky and impulsive behavior as participants advance in their transition through adolescence. This work holds the potential to provide a more detailed mechanistic account of  how reinforcement learning mediates the dynamic relationship between brain and behavior over the course of development.

por.por_cntn:
The overarching goal of this project was to characterize developmental changes in value-based reinforcement learning processes and how they modulate the propensity toward risky and impulsive choice. During the award period, we pursued several lines of research aligned with this high-level goal, and conducted synergistic educational outreach, mentorship, and training activities aimed at fostering broader inclusion in science.


Convergent interdisciplinary literatures distinguish two computational approaches that can be used to evaluate potential actions. “Model-based” learning leverages knowledge of environmental structure to prospectively evaluate which action is currently most beneficial, whereas “model-free” learning fosters a simpler propensity to repeat previously reward actions. Across several studies, we have found that whereas children, adolescents, and adults all demonstrate model-free learning, model-based choice gradually increased into adulthood. Strikingly, even when children failed to use task structure information to pursue reward, they were able to learn the statistical regularities that defined the structure of the task. Paralleling the dissociation between children's learning and use of statistical regularities observed in our studies of model-based learning, we have similarly found that while children readily learn task-relevant causal or statistical information, the use of this information to guide future learning and memory encoding exhibits age-related improvements into adulthood. Moreover, we found that age-related improvements in the use of learned value signals to prioritize memory encoding related to increased engagement of the prefrontal cortex. Collectively this work reveals early maturity of neurocognitive systems that support learning predictive relations, with age-related increases in the ability to flexibly deploy this knowledge to support goal-directed behavior. 


To delay gratification in many real-world contexts, one must learn which actions are causally responsible for delayed rewarding outcomes — a challenge known in the field of reinforcement learning as the temporal “credit assignment” problem. In work currently under revision, we have shown that the ability to learn such intertemporal causal relations also improves from childhood into adolescence, which may contribute to declining choice impulsivity.


Adolescence is proposed to be a period of heightened sensitivity to reward, suggesting that a tendency to overweight positive, relative to negative, outcomes during learning might promote risky decision making. Strikingly, although adolescents indeed reported higher levels of real-world risk taking than children or adults, in our sequential choice task in which risk-taking was equally likely to result in positive and negative outcomes, adolescents exhibited the most risk-averse choices. Computational modeling revealed developmental shifts in the parameters that govern the weight placed on better- or worse-than-expected outcomes (i.e., “prediction errors”), with adolescents selectively overweighting negative prediction errors. Moreover, valence asymmetries in learning were paralleled by corresponding asymmetries in subsequent memory for pictures presented with outcomes on each trial, suggesting that subjective salience of positive and negative outcomes also promotes their persistence in memory. In many real-world contexts in which adolescents take risks (e.g., unsafe driving, unprotected sex), negative choice outcomes are rarely experienced directly. Our data suggest that when adolescents actually experience such negative outcomes, they act as particularly strong deterrents on subsequent risk-taking. 


In related research, we examined the role of agency, or control, in value-based learning across development. We designed a novel, reinforcement learning task that manipulated the degree of control participants had over their learning environments. We found that participants across all ages had better subsequent memory for items encoded with agency but only in the context for which agency was the most useful. In another study, we assessed the extent to which individuals could detect their degree of control over the environment. We found that while children were able to distinguish controllable and uncontrollable conditions, the accuracy of controllability assessments improved with age, and this improvement was mediated by increases in working memory. 


In a novel line of research we examined how reward processing and exploration unfold in the real world, combining GPS-tracking and smartphone affective experience sampling. We found that greater diversity in physical location was associated with greater positive affect. Further, affective sensitivity to diverse experiences was related to functional connectivity between the striatum and the hippocampus, brain regions centrally implicated in reward and novelty processing. In work currently in press, we found that the propensity toward exploration increases across adolescence, and is predictive of adolescents’ self-reported risk taking behavior. 


Throughout the award period, we conducted synergistic educational outreach activities. We gave interactive multi-modal educational presentations about brain development and the neural substrates of decision making in local schools, focusing on underserved communities. We also led lab workshops and tours of our imaging facilities, giving students from diverse backgrounds the opportunity to learn about the practice of cognitive neuroscience. In partnership with the New York Hall of Science, our lab also established a paid ten-week summer research internship for students from their Science Career Ladder Program, providing STEM-focused high school and undergraduate students with hands-on opportunities to participate in our research.
